prompt: Act as if you are a doctor at a large animal shelter. Write a short note to a colleague to ask them to cover your shifts next week because you have a personal emergency. Be sure to explain the situation clearly.
chosen:
Subject: Request for Shift Coverage

Dear [Colleague Name],

I am writing to request shift coverage for next week. I am currently unable to work due to a personal emergency.

I understand that my absence may cause inconvenience, and I apologize for any trouble this may cause. However, I have to attend to this emergency immediately. I have included my schedule for next week below, and I appreciate it if you could cover my shifts.

Thank you for your understanding and assistance during this time. Please let me know if you have any questions or if there is anything else I can do to assist you.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

Schedule for next week:

Monday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM
Tuesday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM
Wednesday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM
Thursday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM
Friday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM
Saturday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM
Sunday: 9:00 AM - 1:00 PM
rejected:
Subject: Request for time off

Dear [Colleague's name],

I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to request time off from my shifts at the animal shelter next week. I have a personal emergency that requires my immediate attention, and I will not be able to work during that time.

The emergency is [briefly explain the situation]. Due to the nature of the situation, I cannot provide any further details at this time. However, I assure you that it is a matter that requires my full attention and requires me to be away from the shelter for an extended period.

I understand that covering shifts at the shelter can be challenging, and I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause. I have already spoken to [name of the person covering your shift], and they have agreed to cover my shifts during this time. I have also made sure to provide them with all the necessary information and instructions to ensure that the animals are well taken care of during my absence.

I appreciate your understanding and support during this difficult time. Please let me know if you have any questions or if there is anything else I can do to assist you during this time.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Best regards,
[Your name]

prompt:
Background:
<start of reference>
August is the cruelest month: never enough daylight, too much heat, no holidays and nothing matters except Septembers dawning responsibilities, but the August of 1994 I was Holden Caulfield, summer camp senior counselor for the junior trail blazers, black and brown children two weeks shy of first, second, and third grade. Nothing is as positive, as motivating a force within ones life as a school bus full of kids singing along to the local radio station blazing hip-hop and R&B. (Imagine this cherubic chorus riding upstate to Ini Kamozes Here Comes the Hotstepper. [Muuur-derah!]) My workday is filled with hazards like chocolate melted sticky swim trunk pockets, insistent sunburn, and the assorted rah rah of parental unsupervision, but those bus rides back from upstate water parks and pools were my favorite times working. Have you ever ridden in a cheesebus with ashy children asleep against you, staring at sudden treesmore numerous than project windowsblurring along the highways like confusion giving way to doubt, the heady smell of dried chlorine and musty towels lulling you into the soft timbre of a Midwest falsetto? Tell me what it is to fall in love with a lightskin girl covering the Isley Brothers. I was not two weeks into 21 years old. I had yet to wear a box cutter in my fifth pocket, or see a semi-automatic aimed at my center mass, to feel its dumbness against my spine. My life was uncertain, save for its unlikely length under my control, like the pilot who falls short of what he says, what he says hes all about, all about. All my homeboys were still alive, just like Aaliyah Dana Haughton, not yet an angel of the cruelest August, begging a boy, who may not be in the mood to learn what he thinks he knows, to look beyond his world and try to find a place for her.
<end of reference>
Task:
Please rewrite this poem to be more concise and focused on the main themes of the poem.
chosen: In the cruelest month of August, when the days are short and the heat is intense, a school bus full of children singing along to hip-hop and R&B serves as a positive force in the life of a senior counselor at a summer camp for black and brown children. The hazards of the job include sticky pockets, sunburn, and the unsupervision of parents, but the bus rides back from upstate water parks and pools are the favorite times of the workday. The author, who is just two weeks shy of his 21st birthday, has yet to experience the dangers of the world, like carrying a box cutter in his fifth pocket or having a semi-automatic aimed at his center mass. The uncertainty of life is offset by the unlikely length of his control over it, like the pilot who falls short of what he says he's all about. The main themes of the poem are the love of a lightskin girl, the untimely death of Aaliyah, and the search for a place to belong.
rejected: My workday is filled with hazards like chocolate melted sticky swim trunk pockets, insistent sunburn, and the assorted rah rah of parental unsupervision, but those bus rides back from upstate water parks and pools were my favorite times working. I was not two weeks into 21 years old. I had yet to wear a box cutter in my fifth pocket, or see a semi-automatic aimed at my center mass, to feel its dumbness against my spine. All my homeboys were still alive, just like Aaliyah Dana Haughton, not yet an angel of the cruelest August, begging a boy, who may not be in the mood to learn what he thinks he knows, to look beyond his world and try to find a place for her.

prompt:
Background:
<start of reference>
Fifteen I got a job at Leggett's, stock boy, fifty cents an hour. Moved upI come from that kind of peopleto toys at Christmas, then Menswear and finally Shoes. Quit to go to college, never worked retail again, but I still really like stores, savor merchandise neatly stacked on tables, sweaters wanting my gliding palm as I walk by, mannequins weirdly sexy behind big glass windows, shoes shiny and just waiting for the right feet. So why in my seventies do Target, Lowes, and Home Depot spin me dizzy and lost, wanting my mother to find me, wipe my eyes, hold my hand all the way out to the car?
<end of reference>
Task:
What is the theme of the text?
chosen: The theme of the text is the narrator's reflection on their job as a stock boy in a department store and how it has affected their relationship with stores and merchandise. They also discuss how their experiences working in retail have impacted their life and their decision to go to college.
rejected: The theme of the text is a man's life story and his struggles with working in retail.

prompt:
Background:
<start of reference>
Its surface temperatures were far too cold for a colony, although the French had set up a couple of mining facilities on its surface. Importantly, at its present position, it lay almost directly between the shift passage Achilles had just exited and the shift passage that eventually lead back to Earth. Therefore, it wouldn't look too strange for Achilles to plot a course close to the planet.

"Here's my plan," Somerville said to the confused faces on the bridge. "As soon as we light off our engines everyone in the system will pick us up on their gravimetric sensors. Our course will make it clear we want to get out of New France and to safety. Whoever the Russian commander is, he will see an opportunity to destroy a large British warship isolated and alone. He'll no doubt move his main fleet to intercept us and may even dispatch a flotilla to harry us and make sure we don't try to attack their ships in orbit. We're going to play along, at least until we get near the sixth planet."

*

Three hours later, the time came for Achilles to make her course change. Sure enough, the Russian commander was moving the main part of his fleet closer to the shift passage that would be Achilles eventual route of escape. He had also dispatched a smaller force to move closer to the colony in case Achilles tried anything. As soon as she turned her nose towards the sixth planet the smaller fleet reacted. They immediately began to decelerate hard to swing deeper into the system. Rightly predicting she would use the planet's gravity to go for the Russian ships orbiting the colony. They hoped to intercept the British ship before she made it to the colony. Up to this point though Somerville had been holding back Achilles' full potential. Once she swung around the sixth planet, using its gravity to sling shot her towards the French colony, he ordered the engines to full power. The extra thirty percent thrust from the engines caught the Russians off guard. They had no answer and so were quickly left astern of the charging Achilles.

The Russian commander had been taken aback by Achilles sudden burst of speed for his response was slow. Eventually, four destroyers began to move out of orbit around New France and formed up to engage Achilles.
<end of reference>
Task:
Write a battle scenario description of the space battle between the Russian and British ships in at least 5 sentences for a space battle scenario game.
chosen: Three hours later, Achilles turned its nose towards the sixth planet. The Russian commander had moved the main part of his fleet closer to the shift passage. He had also dispatched a smaller force to move closer to the colony in case Achilles tried anything. As soon as Achilles turned towards the sixth planet, the smaller fleet reacted. They immediately began to decelerate hard to swing deeper into the system. The Russian commander had been taken aback by Achilles' sudden burst of speed. Eventually, four destroyers began to move out of orbit around New France and formed up to engage Achilles.
rejected: As soon as the engines light off, the Russian commander will send his fleet to intercept Achilles. With her nose turned towards the sixth planet, the Russian fleet will decelerate hard to intercept the British ship before she reaches the French colony. However, the extra thrust from the engines will catch the Russians off guard, and their response will be slow. Four destroyers will eventually move out of orbit around New France to engage Achilles, but they will be left astern of the charging Achilles.

prompt:
Background:
<start of reference>
Opinion: True canaries in coal mine

Friday

Oct 4, 2019 at 5:46 PM

The health of bird populations always has been a key indicator of broader environmental health, so a study demonstrating vast declines in those populations in the United States and Canada is a major concern beyond just the Audubon Society.

According to the study published this week in the journal Science, the total bird population in the two countries has declined by 29% since 1970 — that's 3 billion birds.

The number is even more significant because it cannot be contained to a single threatened species or cause. Rather, it is spread across a wide array of birds, from migratory species to common backyard birds.

"We expected to see continuing declines of threatened species. But for the first time, the results also showed pervasive losses among common birds across all habitats, including backyard birds," said Ken Rosenberg, the study's lead author and a senior scientist at the Cornell University Lab of Ornithology and American Bird Conservancy.

About 90% of the losses affect 12 bird families, including swallows, warblers, finches and sparrows, that are key components of the food chain, seed distribution and pest control.

Grassland birds experienced a 53% population loss over the study period — more than 720 million birds. Shore birds declined by 33% over the last decade. And the volume of spring migration, measured by radar in night skies, declined by 14%.

The study was in the nature of a census and did not seek to determine the causes of the precipitous declines. Some of those causes generally are known, such as predation, building and wind turbine collisions and documented disease outbreaks in some groups.

But since bird population health truly is the coal mine canary regarding broader environmental health, state and federal governments should commission far more detailed studies as a precursor to addressing the environmental issues connected to the decline.

— The Citizens' Voice

Never miss a story

Choose the plan that's right for you.
Digital access or digital and print delivery.
<end of reference>
Task:
What is the author's main point in the article?
chosen: The author's main point is that the decline in bird populations is a significant indicator of broader environmental health, and governments should commission more detailed studies to address the underlying environmental issues.
rejected: The author's main point is that the declining health of bird populations is a major concern because it serves as an indicator of broader environmental health.

prompt:
Background:
<start of reference>
The UAE-supported separatists of the Southern Transitional Council (STC) in Yemen have established a new military force in the southern port city and interim capital, Aden. News of the move was provided by the commander of the Security Belt Forces, the elite military wing of the STC, Brigadier General Mohsen Al-Wali.

According to reports, the so-called Aden Ring Belt Forces will be led by Lieutenant Colonel Naji Al-Yehri, with Major Mohamed Yaslim Al-Sobaihi as Chief of Staff.

The formation of the group threatens to cause further tensions between the UN-recognised Yemeni government and the STC following the 2019 signing of the Riyadh Agreement, which led to a new unity government late last year.

The new armed group may also undermine the military arrangements under the accord, which was intended to facilitate the withdrawal of STC forces from the contested southern Abyan province and their redeployment to focus on the Houthi front lines in the north.

On Sunday, the STC rejected recent appointments made by President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi, including the appointment of a new attorney general and Shura Council head.

Reminder of the fragility of #Yemen's new power-sharing arrangement between north & south: Latest #STC statement alleges that key appointments made by President Hadi on 15JAN without consultation flout the #RiyadhAgreement. If not addressed, it warns "steps will be taken" pic.twitter.com/3Mvc5uqKPs

The STC described the presidential decrees as "unilateral decisions" which "constituted a blatant departure from what has been agreed upon according to the Riyadh deal, and are undermining the consensus process and partnership established between the two parties." It threatened to take "escalating steps in the event that the presidential decisions taken without prior agreement are not addressed."

Unless otherwise stated in the article above, this work by Middle East Monitor is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. If the image(s) bear our credit, this license also applies to them. What does that mean? For other permissions, please contact us.
<end of reference>
Task:
What is the significance of the new military force in Aden, and how might it impact the ongoing conflict in Yemen?
chosen: The formation of the Aden Ring Belt Forces in Yemen, led by the UAE-supported Southern Transitional Council (STC), is a significant development that threatens to further escalate tensions between the UN-recognized Yemeni government and the STC. The new military force could undermine the military arrangements under the Riyadh Agreement, which aimed to facilitate the withdrawal of STC forces from the contested Abyan province and redeployment to focus on the Houthi front lines in the north. The move could also cause tensions between the two parties, as the STC recently rejected recent appointments made by President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi, including the appointment of a new attorney general and Shura Council head. The STC described the presidential decrees as "unilateral decisions" which "constituted a blatant departure from what has been agreed upon according to the Riyadh deal, and are undermining the consensus process and partnership established between the two parties." The formation of the new military force could potentially lead to further conflict in Yemen, exacerbating the ongoing humanitarian crisis and putting more civilians at risk.
rejected: The establishment of a new military force in Aden by the UAE-supported Southern Transitional Council (STC) in Yemen signals a potential threat to the fragile power-sharing arrangement between the north and south of the country. The move could undermine the UN-recognized Yemeni government and the military arrangements under the Riyadh Agreement, which was intended to facilitate the withdrawal of STC forces from the contested Abyan province and their redeployment to focus on the Houthi front lines in the north. The new force may also further exacerbate tensions between the STC and the government, which could have destabilizing consequences for the country's ongoing conflict.

prompt:
Background:
<start of reference>
When I was younger and a lot more naive, I'd tell just about anybody where this body came from. I hung around primarily other people with metaphysical interests, and I thought it was something I could share. Boy did I want to share.

It worked well until the day a new person came into my life, got to know me long enough to get my story, and publicly claimed my history as their own. In fact, I've had that happen a lot. I've even sat in my living room crying tears of drowning hurt as I watched a very tender memory I'd shared on the internet enacted step for step in a popular cartoon movie that came out a couple of years after the fact.

Well I'm all grown up now, and I've learned that I'm not the center of the universe. It's important when finding the truth about your metaphysical situation you get that straight, because the answers aren't just inside of you. They're inside of everyone else. My history is not any more special than someone else's may be. I just know how to tell it better than many people do is all. Maybe certain people could take a few classes on the fine art of storytelling rather than steal someone else's history. Or something.

The main reason why I don't want to bore you with too many details here (and I don't) is because these things are only factors that lead to the shaping of my body and my childhood environment. They're not why I was chosen to be a MILAB. They're just factors in my original makeup, the thing that helped me to come into being. These things I'm going to touch on may be why my father did what he did and possibly was chosen for what he may have done. Or my mother. But they're not why *I* was chosen.

Okay. I'm Native American. I don't mean I'm Cherokee and Irish or some other blend, something that only says that I have an ancestor that was Native American but I'm not. No. I'm Native American. Period.

Yep. I'm red just like every other red person in the world that is not part of the program. Or they're part of the program, but on such a low key level it doesn't matter.
<end of reference>
Task:
Summarize the key points of the text for a student audience in at least 5 sentences.
chosen: This text is about a person who was taken as a child in a government program called a MILAB. This person states that they were not chosen because of their Native American ancestry but because of other factors that may have been part of their parents' makeup. They also state that their history is not special and that everyone has a history.
rejected: A person known as the author was chosen to be a MILAB (military abduction) and is now sharing their story. The author doesn't want to give too many details about their life, but it's clear that their father was involved in their MILAB status. The author states that they don't want to give too much personal information, as it is not necessary for the story. The author also mentions that they are Native American.

Background:
<start of reference>
When I was younger and a lot more naive, I'd tell just about anybody where this body came from. I hung around primarily other people with metaphysical interests, and I thought it was something I could share. Boy did I want to share.

It worked well until the day a new person came into my life, got to know me long enough to get my story, and publicly claimed my history as their own. In fact, I've had that happen a lot. I've even sat in my living room crying tears of drowning hurt as I watched a very tender memory I'd shared on the internet enacted step for step in a popular cartoon movie that came out a couple of years after the fact.

Well I'm all grown up now, and I've learned that I'm not the center of the universe. It's important when finding the truth about your metaphysical situation you get that straight, because the answers aren't just inside of you. They're inside of everyone else. My history is not any more special than someone else's may be. I just know how to tell it better than many people do is all. Maybe certain people could take a few classes on the fine art of storytelling rather than steal someone else's history. Or something.

The main reason why I don't want to bore you with too many details here (and I don't) is because these things are only factors that lead to the shaping of my body and my childhood environment. They're not why I was chosen to be a MILAB. They're just factors in my original makeup, the thing that helped me to come into being. These things I'm going to touch on may be why my father did what he did and possibly was chosen for what he may have done. Or my mother. But they're not why *I* was chosen.

Okay. I'm Native American. I don't mean I'm Cherokee and Irish or some other blend, something that only says that I have an ancestor that was Native American but I'm not. No. I'm Native American. Period.

Yep. I'm red just like every other red person in the world that is not part of the program. Or they're part of the program, but on such a low key level it doesn't matter.
<end of reference>

prompt:
Consider this reference information delimited in """:
"""
Engineers, although not farmers, often support the agricultural industry through design of technology, systems planning and supplying energy for farms. Any engineer with a global perspective on sustainability should have an understanding of the systems in place to provide society with the elements without which life would be impossible.

This chapter will begin with outlining the trends in food production over the last century, how eating habits have changed and how agriculture has adapted to cater for this change in diet for an expanding population. In concurrence with previous chapters, we will then outline the environmental and social issues associated with current farming methods, finishing with suggestions for a sustainable food production system. Also included at the end of the chapter will be case studies of food growing projects that are successfully implementing sustainable practices in food production.

## Trends in Agriculture and Associated Problems

As shown in Chapter 1, the biggest change in agriculture has been supplying food for an exponentially growing population. Primarily, this has resulted in a proportional increase in land use for agriculture. Although the production per acre has increased due to technological innovation (as will be discussed in the next section) the sheer volume of food required for a burgeoning population has put stresses on the land, and as discussed in the previous chapter, water. In many cases farmland has encroached onto natural habitats, destroying natural ecosystems. An example of this is parts of the Amazon being cut down to provide space for soya farms, which in turn feed cattle farms for the meat industry in the West.

The general paradigm in land use has been a shift from a large amount of small, family run farms dispersed evenly across the countryside, to a smaller amount of much bigger farms, employing fewer workers but achieving higher output through the use of large machinery such as tractors. This is evident in some parts of the USA, where there are colossal farms run by only a few workers. These large farms will invariably grow immense fields of one crop which can be farmed efficiently to increase output. This is known as monoculture farming and can lead to a loss in biological diversity and make crops more susceptible to disease.

There are growing concerns about whether the trends of increasing productivity per acre of land can continue while maintaining or restoring the natural resource base upon which agriculture depends.
"""

Write a summary of this text in at least 5 sentences aimed at a general audience.
chosen: Over the last century, food production has increased to supply an expanding population. However, this has resulted in stress on land and water resources. Land use has shifted from many small family farms to fewer, larger farms using large machinery. This is known as monoculture farming, which can lead to a loss of biological diversity and make crops more susceptible to disease. There are concerns about whether the trend of increasing productivity per acre of land can continue while maintaining or restoring the natural resource base upon which agriculture depends.
rejected: In order to provide for an exponentially growing population, the biggest change in agriculture has been supplying food. This has put stress on the land and water. The paradigm in land use has shifted from many small family farms to fewer, much bigger farms.

The pair has limited resources and are forced to make do with what they have, but they refuse to give up on their dream. chosen:
The film starts with two struggling filmmakers, Alex and Jane, who are trying to make it big by creating their own original content. They have limited resources and are forced to make do with what they have.

Despite the challenges they face, Alex and Jane refuse to give up on their dream. They spend their days writing scripts, shooting footage, and editing their films. Their nights are spent trying to get their work seen by anyone who will watch it.

One day, they receive an email from a film festival asking for submissions. They are excited, but also nervous. They have limited time and limited resources to make their submission.

Alex and Jane spend the next few days trying to figure out how to make the best film they can with what they have. They shoot footage with their cell phones, use their apartment as a set, and use their friends as actors.

In the end, they are able to create a short film that they are proud of. They submit it to the film festival and wait. A few days later, they receive an email notifying them that their film has been accepted into the festival.

Alex and Jane are ecstatic. They have made it. They have created something original and it has been recognized. The film ends with them celebrating their success and dreaming of what the future might hold for them.

prompt: Explain the concept of social inclusion in 5 bullet points.
chosen:
1. Social inclusion is the process of ensuring that everyone is involved in society and has access to opportunities and resources.

2. It involves breaking down barriers that prevent people from fully participating in social life, such as discrimination, poverty, and lack of access to education or healthcare.

3. Social inclusion is important because it promotes equality, reduces social tensions, and fosters a sense of community.

4. Governments, non-profit organizations, and individuals can all work to promote social inclusion by addressing the root causes of exclusion and creating policies and programs that support marginalized groups.

5. Some examples of social inclusion initiatives include providing affordable housing, creating job opportunities for people with disabilities, and promoting cultural diversity through events and education.
rejected:
Inclusion in society means to have access to the same opportunities, resources, and rights as others. It is about feeling a sense of belonging and being valued for who you are. 

It means having a voice in decision-making processes that affect your life and being treated with dignity and respect. 

Inclusion is a two-way street that involves both the individual and society. It requires a willingness to understand and appreciate the diversity of people and cultures in our world.

Society can play a crucial role in promoting inclusion by creating an environment that is welcoming and supportive of all individuals, regardless of their background or abilities.

Examples of social inclusion include access to education, healthcare, employment, and political participation.

prompt: How can I write a compelling story about an investigation? Include key details and elements to include, and how to keep the reader engaged.
chosen:
To write a compelling story about an investigation, you can include the following key details and elements:

1. Introduction: Set the scene and introduce the characters and the investigation.

2. Conflict: Create a conflict or problem that the characters need to solve during the investigation.

3. Suspense: Keep the reader engaged by building suspense throughout the story.

4. Evidence: Provide evidence and clues that help the characters solve the conflict.

5. Resolution: Finally, reveal the resolution and tie up any loose ends.

You can use these elements to structure your story and keep the reader engaged. Make sure to use vivid language and descriptive details to bring the story to life.
rejected: To write a compelling story about an investigation, you should include several key details and elements to keep the reader engaged. Firstly, you should set the scene and introduce the characters and the situation. Secondly, you should build the tension and suspense by slowly revealing the details of the investigation. Thirdly, you should provide a satisfying conclusion, whether it is a resolution to the investigation or a cliffhanger. Finally, you should proofread and edit your work to ensure that it is clear, concise, and engaging.

prompt: How can I write a compelling story about an investigation? Include key details and elements to include, and how to keep the reader engaged.

The story could begin with a mysterious event or crime that needs to be solved, and then introduce the main character or characters who are tasked with the investigation. As the story progresses, the reader could be provided with clues and evidence that help to build the suspense and keep them guessing. It might be helpful to include a twist or surprise at the end to surprise the reader and leave them feeling satisfied. Some key details to include could be the motivation of the characters, the stakes involved, and the challenges they face along the way. The story could also be enriched by adding in some descriptive language and imagery to help bring the setting and characters to life. Overall, the key to keeping the reader engaged is to provide enough details and suspense to keep them interested without giving away too much too soon.

prompt:
Read this for context:
<start of reference>
Are they real? We have pages of kitchen utensils and books and candlesticks and nibs, but the charcoal pencil and new sketchpad are squat as aubergines in her hands in front of this display. With bad weather forecast and light silting up in cramped windows, we are the only visitors. The year settles in a corner of the room, has removed its white gloves, tip by tip, and set to one side its summer purse of bibelots and sheen. Half-term of her final year, we are sightseers intent on moors. In the morning, her windcheater and red wellies will bestow the dust of summer festivals upon sullen, wind-soaked sheep. We will park, and walk ourselves into the final, cutting rain between pages of her favorite book. She wants to go all the way to Top Withens, or the house they say must have been Top Withens, given its loneliness and set. But now is artifacts and souvenirs: a perfume with too much musk in it, a jar of damson jam which we probably wont open until past its sell-by date. We are buying the word damson. And we are buying time. Are they real? she asks me, and I watch her reckon the distance between what should and should never be seen. We have fallen short. She draws, and what she draws is rain falling slant inside the bedroom; the bed as a box of leaves and stones and, within the display case, she hangs from the clothes rail, little moons. On the mannequin, water lilies stand in for morning dress, and the backdrop is marbled in what looks to me like veins and arteries. But when I flick through the sketchpad in the B&B, all the pages, what is left of them, are clean. Next day, she leaves it in the car. When she moves away, she will leave it again, a sketchpad with no name on it and only the faintest traces of where she made skies of darned linen, and unfastened every stitch.
<end of reference>
Your task is to:
Using imagery from the poem, summarize the experience of the mother and daughter visiting ruins and musing about the past in at least 5 sentences for a general audience.
chosen: The mother and daughter are visiting ruins in the Yorkshire Moors. The daughter is holding a charcoal pencil and new sketchpad, feeling out of place in front of the artifacts and souvenirs. The mother and daughter are buying time and the word "damson." The daughter draws a scene of rain falling slant inside a bedroom and hanging from a clothes rail. The backdrop is marbled with what looks like veins and arteries. The sketchpad is left in the car, and when the daughter moves away, she will leave it again with no name on it and only faint traces of where she made skies of darned linen.
rejected: In the poem, a mother and daughter visit ruins on a moor in England during half-term of the daughter's final year of school. The mother observes the daughter struggling with the weight of the charcoal pencil and new sketchpad in front of a display of kitchen utensils and books. The mother notices that the year has removed its white gloves and set aside its summer purse of bibelots and sheen, leaving a sullen, wind-soaked atmosphere. The mother and daughter plan to walk to Top Withens or the house they say must have been Top Withens given its loneliness and setting. While they buy souvenirs, the daughter draws rain falling slant inside the bedroom and hangs from the clothes rail, drawing water lilies in morning dress. The mother notices that the sketchpad is clean when she looks through it in the B&B, and the daughter leaves it in the car. When the daughter moves away, she will leave the sketchpad again, only with faint traces of where she made skies of darned linen and unfastened every stitch.

prompt:
Read this for context:
<start of reference>
Michelin Patents A Reverse System For Motorcycles

The system would work with any bike, not just large ones.

Michelin has patented a device that could provide any motorcycle with a reversing system, thanks to a small electric motor attached to the back wheel.

We've all suffered the pain, or at least the inconvenience, of having to push a motorcycle backward in or out of a parking space. Even with a small bike, all it takes is a small uphill slope to give you a workout. Unlike large Gold Wings and Harleys, as well as some electric bikes, most of us don't have a reverse gear to help.

Gallery: Michelin Motorcycle Reverse Patent Drawings

3Photos

Michelin's solution is quite simple. Rather than adding gears or electric motors to the transmission, it's a completely independent system. It attaches to the rear swingarm the same way as the mudguards and license plate holders of many modern motorcycles. It could even be integrated with these parts from the factory. Small electric motors press two or three rollers against the back tire, which then turns the back wheel. These rollers retract from the tire during normal riding. The system even has its own lithium-ion battery, which eliminates the need for big ugly wiring from the bike's main battery.

Being electric, this device could supply not only a reverse gear but also assistance with forward movement without using the main engine. The patent says the system would move the bike at one kilometer per hour (0.6 miles per hour), and on up to a ten percent slope. That's where the forward option could come in particularly handy.

While not everyone would benefit from this option, it would make bikes so equipped more accessible to smaller or weaker riders. People who can only tip-toe a bike would then be able to safely move it without relying on their own foot power to do it. The only problem I see with this system is that many people remove the hardware that sticks out behind the back wheel because it looks ugly. That would remove the reverse system as well. I suppose riders who don't need it could still do it if the appearance is that important to them.
<end of reference>
Your task is to:
Could you please provide a list of potential drawbacks to a motorcycle with a reverse system?
chosen:
1. Cost: Implementing a reverse system on a motorcycle could increase the cost of the motorcycle, making it more expensive for consumers.
2. Weight: Adding a reverse system to a motorcycle could add extra weight to the bike, which could impact its handling and performance.
3. Balance: A reverse system could change the bike's center of gravity, making it more difficult to balance, especially at low speeds.
4. Maintenance: The reverse system could require additional maintenance and repair, which could be costly and time-consuming.
5. Aesthetics: The reverse system could change the look of the motorcycle, making it less aesthetically pleasing to some riders.
6. Reliability: The reverse system could be prone to malfunction, which could be dangerous and potentially cause accidents.
7. Limited use: The reverse system may only be useful in certain situations, such as when parking on a hill, which could make it a less valuable feature for some riders.
8. Safety: The reverse system could make the motorcycle more difficult to control, increasing the risk of accidents and injuries.
rejected: The drawbacks of a motorcycle with a reverse system include the added weight and complexity of the system, which may impact the bike's handling and performance. Additionally, the system may not be suitable for all types of motorcycles, and may not be compatible with certain aftermarket parts or modifications. Furthermore, the system may not be effective on steep slopes or in certain road conditions. Finally, the added weight and complexity may increase the cost of the motorcycle.

prompt:
Read this for context:
<start of reference>
Urijah visits a local museum because she wants to learn more about ancient cultures. She is particularly interested in seeing the exhibits on Ancient Egypt and Greece. She spends several hours walking around the museum, admiring the artifacts and reading the information panels.

Urijah: Wow, this is incredible! I've always been interested in ancient cultures, but seeing all of this up close is really something else.
Curator: Yes, we're very proud of our collection. We have some of the most comprehensive displays on Ancient Egypt and Greece in the country.
Urijah: I can see that! I'm particularly interested in those two cultures right now. Do you mind if I ask you a few questions about them?
Curator: Of course not. What would you like to know?
Urijah: Well, I was reading about the Pharaohs and their tombs. It said that they were buried with all of their possessions. Why is that?
Curator: The Egyptians believed that in order to reach the afterlife, they had to take everything they needed with them. So their tombs were stocked with food, clothing, weapons, furniture, and anything else they might need in the afterlife.
Urijah: That's really interesting. I also read that Ancient Greeks believed in gods and goddesses who ruled over different areas of life. Do you know why they came up with that idea?
Curator: The Greeks wanted to explain the natural world and the human experience. They believed that the gods and goddesses controlled everything from love and wisdom to agriculture and war. By creating these beings, they gave order to their world.
Urijah: That makes sense. I'm also curious about daily life in these cultures. Can you tell me more about what people did on a day-to-day basis?
Curator: In Ancient Egypt, most people were farmers or herders since the country was mostly desert. They had to be very careful with their water usage since it was such a precious resource. Daily life revolved around irrigation and farming schedules. In Ancient Greece, daily life depended on where you lived since there were many different city-states. If you lived in Athens, for example, you might spend your days going to the marketplace or attending public events at the agora
<end of reference>
Your task is to:
What kind of museum is depicted in the text?
chosen: Urijah visits a local museum, so the museum is a local one.
rejected: Urijah visits a local museum.

prompt:
Read this for context:
Michel goes to temple to learn more about Judaism. He talks to the rabbi about his faith and how he can become a better Jew. Michel also attends services and participates in different religious activities at the temple.

Michel: So, rabbi, I'm really interested in learning more about Judaism. Can you tell me a bit about your faith and how I can become a better Jew?
Rabbi: Of course, Michel. Judaism is a beautiful faith that has been around for thousands of years. It is based on the belief in one God who created the world and everything in it. Jews believe that they have a special relationship with God and are chosen to be his people. As such, Jews have certain responsibilities, like observing the Sabbath and following Jewish law.
Michel: That sounds really interesting. I'd like to learn more about Jewish law. What does that involve?
Rabbi: Jewish law, or halakha, governs every aspect of our lives as Jews. It covers everything from how we pray and worship to what we eat and how we dress. Halakha is based on the Torah, which is the first five books of the Hebrew Bible. The Torah contains 613 commandments that Jews are expected to follow.
Michel: Wow, that's a lot! I'm not sure I could ever remember all of those commandments!
Rabbi: Don't worry, Michel, you don't have to memorize all 613 commandments! Just by living your life according to Jewish values and traditions, you will naturally be following most of them. And as you learn more about Judaism and grow in your faith, you will slowly start to incorporate more of the commandments into your life.
Michel: That makes sense. I'm also interested in learning more about Jewish traditions and customs. Can you tell me about some of those?
Rabbi: Sure! There are many different Jewish traditions and customs, ranging from religious rituals to cultural practices. Some of the most common traditions include celebrating holidays like Passover and Hanukkah, observing the Sabbath, and circumcised boys becoming Bar or Bat Mitzvah at the age of 13.
Michel: That sounds like a lot of fun! I'm definitely interested in learning more about all of these things. Thank you so much for your time, rabbi.

Your task is to:
How does embodied Judaism influence the way that Jewish people practice their faith?
chosen: Embodied Judaism has a significant impact on the way that Jewish people practice their faith. This approach emphasizes the physical aspects of the religion, such as the rituals and customs that are performed with the body. This can include things like hand washing, which represents the importance of cleanliness in Jewish tradition, or the dietary laws that require Jews to avoid certain foods, such as pork. These practices can help to reinforce the connection between the physical and spiritual aspects of the faith, and can help to create a sense of community among Jewish people.
rejected: Embodied Judaism is a way of living and experiencing Jewish tradition and values through physical activity. This can include practicing Jewish rituals, such as prayer and Torah study, through physical movements and gestures. For example, some synagogues have been known to incorporate dancing and movement into their services. This approach to Judaism emphasizes the connection between the body and the spirit, and the importance of physical activity in the spiritual journey.

prompt:
Read this for context:
Mission Foods, a subsidiary of Gruma Corporation, is an American manufacturer of tortillas and tortilla-related products based in Irving, Texas.

History
Mission Foods was founded as a subsidiary of Grupo Maseca in California in 1977 as a brand name to sell the company's tortillas in the American marketplace. It is one of the world's largest producers of flatbread, tortilla and corn flour products with factories in North and Central America, Europe, Asia and Australia. A tortilla manufacturing plant was opened in Dallas in 1982. Mission Foods launched the Mission brand in Australia in 2009 with a plant located in Epping, Victoria.

Sponsorships
In January 2009, Australian media reported Mission Foods had agreed on a sponsorship deal with Australian Rules Football club the Western Bulldogs. The deal is worth $4.5 million over 3 years. In June 2020, Mission Foods and the Western Bulldogs announced a further three-year extension of their sponsorship agreement which will run to the end of 2023.

Mission sponsored a tortilla factory attraction between 2001 and 2011 in the then-named Disney California Adventure Park theme park.  The factory demonstrated tortilla production on a miniaturized, low-speed automated production line, provided samples of tortillas, and demonstrated recipes to park guests.

Mission Foods is a  major netball sponsor. They have sponsored both Queensland Firebirds  team and Netball Singapore. They have sponsored several international netball tournaments hosted in Singapore under including the 2011 World Netball Championships, the 2014 Asian Netball Championships and the Netball Singapore Nations Cup. In April 2019, Mission Foods was announced as a partner of McLaren Racing for both the Indianapolis 500 and Formula One

Product Lines
Mission Foods has a range of tortilla products ranging from the traditional corn and flour tortillas to whole wheat and flavored varieties. Most of Mission Foods products are classified as kosher and Halal. Mission also sells several varieties of tortilla chips.

Your task is to:
Write a summary of Mission Foods in at least 5 sentences for general readers, including details of the company, its history, and products.

prompt:
Read this for context:
Slo una sombra?/Only a Shadow (Ester IV)?, from the series Santos y sombras/Saints and Shadows, 19931994, by Muriel Hasbun My daughter gathers the seeds she finds in our desert, calls them spiritsthe spirits are us, she says when I worry those orbs in my fingers to conjure her birth. The winds first thought is to craft those seeds: vessels when the tree worries shes not enough of a multiplicity, that she will burn into the cosmos. The cosmos is no thought, no worry, more than us, but less than wind, and the wind is only the infinite, not the bodys death, which is, after all, only a particle, but time formless as space. This is only if the wind worries at all. The seed doesnt think she is the doubling ambition of a vessel. In the wind, the idea of the copy is translated by time. We were once that idea. My daughter collects me in a box marked for spirits where I unsettle the other seeds begging for wind so that my sound will echo a thousand miles away. My daughter was the pulse I toss into the wind with the seeds. Particles of us pass over like whispers from the cosmos, the clatter the wind makes. I worry birds will take her into themselves, that shell become a fleck of their transience, but this is how we furrow ourselves into the cosmos, the twine of our breaths into wind, into carbon, into the trees colossal fingers reaching back from under the earth.

Your task is to:
What is the author's perspective on the connection between humans and the natural world?
chosen: The author sees humans as a part of the natural world, stating that "we were once that idea" of the seed's doubling ambition. They also describe the seed as a "vessel" that worries about its ability to "conjure" the multiplicity of the tree, implying that the seed and the tree are connected in some way. Additionally, the author sees the seed as a "vessel" that is translated by time, and that the idea of the copy is "translated" into the seed by time. This suggests that the seed is a manifestation of the idea of the copy in the natural world.
rejected: The author views humans as a part of the natural world, with a connection to the cosmos, the earth, and the wind.

My daughter collects me in a box marked for spirits where I unsettle the other seeds begging for wind so that my sound will echo a thousand miles away. My daughter was the pulse I toss into the wind with the seeds. Particles of us pass over like whispers from the cosmos, the clatter the wind makes. I worry birds will take her into themselves, that shell become a fleck of their transience, but this is how we furrow ourselves into the cosmos, the twine of our breaths into wind, into carbon, into the trees colossal fingers reaching back from under the earth.

Your task is to:
What is the author's perspective on the connection between humans and the natural world?
chosen: The author sees humans as a part of the natural world, with our bodies made of the same elements as the rest of the cosmos. They describe this connection using imagery of seeds and vessels, with the wind as the force that both creates and destroys. The author seems to believe that this connection is necessary for us to fully understand our place in the world and to find peace.
rejected: The author views humans as a part of the natural world, with a connection to the cosmos, the earth, and the wind.

prompt:
Read this for context:
The Aloe vera plant has been used for thousands of years to heal a variety of conditions, most notably burns, wounds, skin irritations, and constipation. It is grown in subtropical and tropical locations, including South Africa, Latin America, and the Caribbean. Aloe was one of the most frequently prescribed medicines throughout most of the 18th and 19th centuries and it remains one of the most commonly used herbs in the United States today. However, oral use of aloe for constipation is no longer recommended, as it can have severe side effects.

Aloe gel, made from the central part of the aloe leaf, is a common household remedy for minor cuts and burns, as well as sunburns. It can be found in many commercial skin lotions and cosmetics. Aloe contains active compounds that may reduce pain and inflammation and stimulate skin growth and repair. It is also an effective moisturizing agent. For this reason, aloe vera gel has gained tremendous popularity for the relief of burns. In one study, burn sites treated with aloe healed completely in less than 16 days compared to 19 days for sites treated with silver sulfadiazine. In a review of the scientific literature, researchers found that patients who were treated with aloe vera healed an average of almost 9 days sooner than those who were not treated with the medicinal plant. However, other studies show mixed results. At least one study found that aloe actually delayed healing. Aloe is best used for minor burns and skin irritations and should never be applied to an open wound.

Although aloe is 99 percent water, aloe gel also contains substances known as glycoproteins and polysaccharides. Glycoproteins speed the healing process by stopping pain and inflammation while polysaccharides stimulate skin growth and repair. These substances may also stimulate the immune system.

Your task is to:
Give me a summary regarding the use of aloe when treating burns. It should be more than fifty words long and be written using an informational tone.
chosen: The Aloe vera plant is a popular household remedy for minor burns, as well as sunburns. Aloe contains active compounds that may reduce pain and inflammation and stimulate skin growth and repair. It is also an effective moisturizing agent. In one study, burn sites treated with aloe healed completely in less than 16 days compared to 19 days for sites treated with silver sulfadiazine. Patients who were treated with aloe vera healed an average of almost 9 days sooner than those who were not treated with the medicinal plant. However, other studies show mixed results. At least one study found that aloe actually delayed healing. Aloe is best used for minor burns and skin irritations and should never be applied to an open wound.
rejected: Aloe vera gel is a popular home remedy for minor burns, including sunburns. The gel can be applied directly to the burn site, where it may reduce pain and inflammation, and stimulate skin growth and repair. However, it should never be applied to an open wound. Aloe is best used for minor burns and skin irritations and should never be applied to an open wound.

prompt:
Refer to the information below to help with the following  delimited in ###:
###
Central America braces for 'extremely dangerous' Hurricane Eta

MANAGUA: Hurricane Eta was hours from making landfall in Central America on Tuesday after gaining strength in the Caribbean Sea, threatening Honduras and Nicaragua with catastrophic winds and floods.

The "extremely dangerous" weather system was packing winds of 150 miles (240 kilometers) an hour as it barrelled towards the Nicaraguan coast, the US National Hurricane Center said in its midnight advisory.

Only the community's men remained to protect the houses, he said. The women and children have already been evacuated from the village of some 800 people.

"If the situation becomes more dangerous," Lackwood said, the men would leave too.

Other regions across the Caribbean and Central America were also facing a mauling from Eta, as the NHC said that "flash flooding and river flooding would be possible across Jamaica, southeast Mexico, El Salvador, southern Haiti, and the Cayman Islands."

"We have managed to evacuate more than 3,000 families with the active participation of our army from Caribbean communities," such as Prinzapolka and the Miskito Cays, Nicaragua's Vice President and first lady Rosario Murillo said.

Those families have been moved to shelters in high, safe areas, said Murillo.

Both Nicaragua, with more than six million people, and neighboring Honduras, with more than nine million, issued red alerts over Eta's imminent arrival.

Some 100,000 people along the Nicaraguan coast, mostly in indigenous communities likely to be hit hard by the hurricane.

'Totally vulnerable'

Dangerous storm surges are expected to raise water levels by up to 18 feet (five meters) above normal tide in areas along the northeastern coast of Nicaragua, and up to five feet along the coast of Honduras, where a tropical storm warning was in force.

"There is some concern from the population, there are many flood areas, people are packing their goods and looking for ways to get out to shelters," said Limbort Bucardo, a resident of the town of Bilwi.
###

Which of the following best describes the disaster described in the text?
- A volcanic eruption
- A hurricane
- A drought
- A wildfire
chosen:
A hurricane

Hurricane Eta was approaching Central America as the reference text was written. It is expected to make landfall in Nicaragua and Honduras, where storm surges and heavy rainfall are expected to cause widespread flooding and destruction. The hurricane is classified as "extremely dangerous" and the population in the affected areas has been advised to evacuate.
rejected: A hurricane

prompt:
Refer to the information below to help with the following  delimited in ###:
###
Hilton announces additional measures to reduce its cost structure

The novel coronavirus (Covid-19) has created unprecedented challenges for the travel and tourism industry. Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc took early and decisive action to boost liquidity and reduce corporate expenditures.

Hilton has announced additional measures to reduce its cost structure, including the intended reduction of approximately 2,100 corporate roles globally, and the extension of previously announced furloughs, reduced hours, and corporate pay reductions for up to an additional 90 days.

Christopher J Nassetta, president & CEO, Hilton, said, "Never in Hilton's 101-year history has our industry faced a global crisis that brings travel to a virtual standstill. Hospitality will always be a business of people serving people, which is why I am devastated that to protect our business, we have been forced to take actions that directly impact our team members. Our company's spirit has always been grounded in a culture that supports our team members and delivers hospitality for our guests. We will keep that spirit alive, and when the world begins to travel again, we will be ready to welcome them back."

Corporate team members whose roles are affected by these actions will receive severance pay, outplacement support, access to online Hilton alumni resources, access to an expedited recruitment process when travel resumes, extended access to the Go Hilton Team Member travel programme and extended Team Member Hilton Honors status.

Follow Us

Express Food & Hospitality is the most reliable source of information for the Indian hospitality industry. It is published by Global Fairs & Media Pvt. Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of The Indian Express Group. From news and analysis to latest policy updates, articles on F&B, tech talk by experts to manpower management issues – Express Food & Hospitality is India's most comprehensive publication for the hospitality sector and has a wide readership across the country.
###

What is the main idea of the press release? Try to summarize it in a few sentences.
chosen: The main idea of the press release is that Hilton has announced additional measures to reduce its cost structure, including the intended reduction of approximately 2,100 corporate roles globally and the extension of previously announced furloughs, reduced hours, and corporate pay reductions for up to an additional 90 days. The company's president and CEO, Christopher J. Nassetta, states that these actions are necessary due to the unprecedented challenges created by the COVID-19 pandemic and that the company's spirit is grounded in a culture that supports its team members and delivers hospitality for its guests.
rejected: The main idea of the press release is that Hilton has announced additional measures to reduce its cost structure, including the intended reduction of approximately 2,100 corporate roles globally, and the extension of previously announced furloughs, reduced hours, and corporate pay reductions for up to an additional 90 days.

prompt:

###
The lesson: do not wait until the statute of limitations is about to expire before you protect your rights.

**Claims Against a Government Entity**

If you have a claim against a governmental entity, such as a town, municipality, county, or state, certain requirements must be met. A verified claim form must be served on the authorized agent for the governmental entity. Serving a valid claim form on the government is a prerequisite to bringing a legal case against the government. The name and address of the authorized agent who can accept service of the claim form is required to be kept as a matter of public record with the auditor in the county in which the entity is located. With claims against the state of Washington, the agent who is authorized to accept service of the claim form is the state's Division of Risk Management in Olympia, Washington.

To be valid, the claim form must contain certain information, including a description of the conduct and circumstances that brought about the injury or damage, a description of the injury or damage, the time and place the injury or damage occurred, the names of all persons involved, the residence of the claimant for a period of six months immediately before the claim arose, and a statement of the amount of damages claimed.

It is important to note that the content and service of the claim form must substantially comply with the requirements of the statute. Failure to comply substantially may result in the claim being denied and/or dismissed by a court of law. Once a claim form has been properly verified, presented, and served on the appropriate governmental entity, you must wait a period of 60 days before a lawsuit can be filed in court.
###

Summarize the legal requirements for filing claims against government entities in at least 5 sentences aimed at legal practitioners.
chosen: When filing a claim against a government entity, it must be done in a specific manner and within a certain timeframe. It must be served on the authorized agent for the government within the time limit. This agent's information can be found on file with the auditor in the county where the entity is located. The claim form must be filled out with the required information and signed under oath. Failure to do so can result in the claim being denied and/or dismissed. There is a 60-day waiting period before the claim can be taken to court.
rejected: The article provides information about filing a claim against a government entity, including the requirements for serving a valid claim form on the government and the necessary information that must be included in the claim form. It also highlights the importance of substantial compliance with the statute's requirements and the 60-day waiting period before filing a lawsuit in court. Additionally, the article provides information about the authorized agent who can accept service of the claim form for different government entities. The article is useful for legal practitioners who may need to file a claim against a government entity on behalf of a client.

prompt:
Refer to the information below to help with the following  delimited in ###:
###
To think I used to be so good at going to pieces gobbling my way through the cops and spooking whats left of the girls. Howd I get so far, sloughing off one knuckle at a time, jerking my mossy pelt along ruined streets? Those insistent, dreadful thuds when we stacked our futile selves against locked doors. Our mumbles and groans! Such hungry nights! Staggering through the grit of looted malls, plastered with tattered flags of useless currency, Id slobbered all over the busted glass and merchandise of America... But first youll have to figure out those qualities separating whats being alive from whos already dead. Most of you will flunk that. Next learn how to want one thing over and over, night after night. Most of you are good at that. Dont get tired. Dont cough into your leftovers. Dont think. Always stand by your hobgoblin buddies. Clutch at whatevers there. Learn to sniff out sundowns.
###

Please rewrite this poem in iambic pentameter, with a consistent rhyme scheme.
chosen:
O wretched soul, once filled with glee,
In conquest of the law, and frighted flight,
How hast thou fallen, day by day,
To lose thy grip, and stray from sight.

With heavy hands, and thumping chest,
We stood, and braved the bolted door,
Our moans and cries, a horrid mess,
So hungry were we, so poor.

Through malls, we marauded and weaved,
With flags, of paper, we were served,
Our bellies, once so filled, were grieved,
To see such bounty, no more in store.

Yet, still we fought, so very much,
To stay alive, with all our might,
To want, and want, each night and dusk,
And never tire, or doubt our might.

So hold thy friends, those hobgoblins, dear,
And clutch the night, with all thy might,
And find thy sundown, with care,
And learn to want, with all thy sight.

prompt:
Reference:
<start of reference>
Castration case: CBI records Dera chief's statement

The enforcement directorate (ED) has also initiated an exercise to identify the movable and immovable assets of Dera sect.

Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh (Photo: AFP/File)

New Delhi: The CBI, which is probing the alleged forced castration of around 400 followers at Sirsa ashram of Dera Sacha Sauda sect, has recorded the statement of jailed Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh in connection with the case.

It may be noted self-styled godman Gurmeet Ram Rahim was on August 28 sentenced to 20 years in jail in a rape case by a special CBI court in Panchkula (Haryana).

With the special court's permission, the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) officials recorded Mr Singh's statement at a Rohtak prison where he is serving 20-year jail term, sources said.

The CBI had registered the case in January, 2015, on the orders of the Punjab and Haryana high court. The agency registered the case of alleged criminal conspiracy for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means among other charges under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) against Mr Singh and others.

"Preliminary investigation by the agency revealed that the surgeries were allegedly performed in the presence of two-three doctors. The agency sleuths already ascertained the identity of these doctors," sources said. They said the agency sleuths have gathered enough evidence pertaining to complaints against the Dera chief.

Sources said the petitioner, Hansraj Chauhan, alleged that around 400 male devotees belonging to states including, Haryana, Punjab and Rajasthan were allegedly castrated at the Dera headquarters after its head falsely claimed that the "castration would lead to realisation of God through him".

The enforcement directorate (ED) has also initiated an exercise to identify the movable and immovable assets of Dera sect. The Punjab and Haryana high court recently asked the ED and income tax department to look into allegations of money laundering in the Dera sect's functioning.
<end of reference>
Instruction:
From the text given, extract the total number of castration cases that took place in the Dera sect.
chosen: The total number of castration cases that took place in the Dera sect is around 400.
rejected: The enforcement directorate (ED) has also initiated an exercise to identify the movable and immovable assets of Dera sect. The Punjab and Haryana high court recently asked the ED and income tax department to look into allegations of money laundering in the Dera sect's functioning.

In the depths of despair,
A man sits alone in despair,
His mind wanders along the iron tracks,
The staples that divide his fathers spine.

Before him sits a stranger,
Whose father also waited for the condor,
Whose lips were parched from years of devotion.
Their eyes barely meet,
For fear of setting off some unknown reaction.

The man shifts in his seat,
Each movement a delicate dance.
He fears a cave-in, a shattering of all he knows.

All in all, he is but a broken man,
Whose bark is worse than his bite.
But this is how it starts,
At last, I realize.

I thought you were someone else,
But instead, I find myself alone,
With only the rattle of the beetle files,
To keep me company.

He frowns,
And for a moment, I fear he may break.
But then he speaks,
Establishing his presence with his palms.

Tell me,
He says.
Does that happen often, lamb?

prompt:
Reference:
<start of reference>
The term “marine microbe” covers a diversity of microorganisms, including Bacteria, Archaea, Eukaryota, and viruses. These organisms are exceedingly small—only 1/8000th the volume of a human cell and spanning about 1/100th the diameter of a human hair. Up to a million of them live in just one milliliter of seawater.
Despite being found everywhere on Earth—in your belly, dirt, the oceans—the diversity and distribution of microorganisms remain under-sampled and uncharted, especially in the deep sea.
We know that microbes are the Earth’s processing factories of biological, geological, and chemical (biogeochemical) interactions. Most marine microbes exist in highly organized and interactive communities that are versatile, complex, and difficult to analyze. They account for more than 98 percent of ocean biomass and possess as much variability as the environments they inhabit.
These organisms are capable of existing in practically any environment and garnering energy from a variety of sources, ranging from solar radiation to chemosynthesis. They play many different roles in the marine environment, from being the base of the food chain to controlling much of the flow of marine energy and nutrients and being essential to the ocean’s health.
Marine microbe communities can evolve rapidly in response to environmental shifts and could be used as indicators of ocean change. In fact, marine microbes can be “the canary in the coal mine” for the marine environment. In addition, they are also drivers of change in the ocean. Consequently, it is very important to acquire baseline information about these microorganisms against which future changes could be identified.
<end of reference>
Instruction:
With the article being very scientific, who would be the targeted audience of the passage?  Would the way it is written intimidate particular groups of people?  The answer should be 1 paragraph in length and explain your reasoning in as much detail as possible.
chosen: The targeted audience for this article would be people interested in scientific research. This could be students doing research, or professors doing a literature review. The writing style does have the potential to intimidate some people, especially those not accustomed to scientific writing. The main reasons for this are the writing style and the vocabulary used.
rejected: The targeted audience of the passage would be scientists, or at least people interested in science. The article is quite long, and the language is quite complex, so it may intimidate those who are not used to reading scientific material.

The taste of their blood had deafened him to my commands, so I went to him like an angry god and chased him away with my staff and rod, inflicting a wound also in his side for him to go on licking, to wash their blood from off his tongue with his own blood, and then I kneeled in the grass to regard his kill while the mother keened inside the woods not far away. Oh, what a mess they were with their heads snapped back and wings unhinged. I picked up the bodies like bloody socks and prayed to the god in charge of this field for my own weakness to feel this much for slaughtered chicks. For an understanding of his need to kill the most vulnerable thing, whether hungry or not.

prompt:
Reference:
This pretty much crippled my investigation.

The situation between Suzy and Mr. McCarthy contributed to my lack of progress as well. Although Mr. McCarthy was still delivering our mail, it was only because I made sure that Suzy was in the house when he made his rounds. I felt like Sara making sure her cats are put up before her parents get home.

After a lackluster week, Saturday provided me with a new opportunity. The Bradford Red Devils were playing the Milan Bulldogs for the county softball championship. Hundreds of possible suspects would be at the game. I would be able to interrogate anyone without restrictions. Hopefully, I could make up for lost time.

After lunch, I put Suzy on his leash and walked over to Sara's house. Much like what we had planned at the school crossing, we would take turns interviewing suspects. One of us would have to keep track of Suzy at all times. Normally, I would let Suzy run free, but Coach Nelson banned him from all softball games unless he was on a leash. Suzy got carried away last year and tried to be part of the game. It wasn't entirely Suzy's fault. He thought he was supposed to fetch the ball when it was hit into the outfield. It was quite a spectacle watching the entire Red Devils team chase Suzy around the ball park trying to retrieve the ball from him. The only problem was that while they were busy chasing Suzy, the base runner was allowed to roam the bases freely. What would have been a single turned into a game winning home run for the opposing team. Luckily, the loss didn't hurt the team's ranking. Nevertheless, Coach Nelson wasn't amused when a local newspaper published photos of the chase and credited Suzy with the game winning RBI for the opposition. In addition, the story mockingly questioned whether or not Suzy was listed on the official roster of players.

Coach Nelson spotted us as soon as we stepped through the admittance gate. Although he was in the middle of warming up with the team, he threw his mitt down and headed in our direction.

Instruction:
From the text given, extract the suspect's name, what they did, and why they did it.
chosen:
- Suzy: tried to be part of the game by fetching the ball when it was hit into the outfield.
- Coach Nelson: was not amused when a local newspaper published photos of the chase and credited Suzy with the game winning RBI for the opposition.
rejected: Suzy, tried to be part of the game, he thought he was supposed to fetch the ball when it was hit into the outfield.

prompt:
The following information may be useful:
<start of reference>
Less than one year after previously agreeing to a new four-year contract, Temple University and the Temple University Police Association (TUPA) have reached agreement on terms of a new contract that both sides believe will assist with recruiting and retaining highly-qualified police officers for Temple‘s Department of Public Safety.  

“On a both a national and local level, we know that this is a very challenging time to recruit and retain police officers, which is why we are excited to come to an agreement like this,” said Sharon Boyle, vice president for human resources. “We knew that we needed to do more to assist with recruitment and retention, and this is why we reached out to TUPA’s leadership to re-enter into negotiations for additional provisions, even though we were just seven months into the prior agreement. We’re glad we were able to get this deal done.” 

The re-negotiation process started in February when Vice President for Public Safety Jennifer Griffin approached TUPA to specifically to work on a recruitment and retention strategy for the department’s police officers. Over the last few months, the two parties have met regularly, culminating in this latest agreement. 

“Our police officers work immensely hard to protect this community, and it is great to see them further compensated for their hard work,” Griffin said. “We need to make Temple University a place where police officers want to work and join the Department of Public Safety, and we think this new agreement is a great step in that direction.” 

TUPA took over as the official labor union representing the members of the Temple University Police Department in March 2022. The organization represents the police officers, dispatchers and security officers employed by Temple University. 

TUPA's previous salary and benefits package was already on par with or exceeded that of every other university law enforcement agency in the City of Philadelphia. This new agreement ensures that will continue into the future. These adjustments were made possible, in part, by the generosity of a Commonwealth grant, for which Temple is grateful. 

The agreement is in effect until June 2027.
<end of reference>

Metatarsalgia (met-uh-tahr-SAL-juh) is a condition in which the ball of your foot becomes painful and inflamed. You might develop it if you participate in activities that involve running and jumping. There are other causes as well, including foot deformities and shoes that are too tight or too loose. Although generally, not serious, metatarsalgia can sideline you. Fortunately, at-home treatments, such as ice and rest, often relieve symptoms. Wearing proper footwear with shock-absorbing insoles or arch supports might prevent or minimize future problems with metatarsalgia. Distance runners are at risk of metatarsalgia, primarily because the front of the foot absorbs significant force when a person runs. But anyone who participates in a high-impact sport is at risk, especially if their shoes fit poorly or are worn.
<end of reference>

In this article, the author is explaining the condition of metatarsalgia and the different factors that may cause it. This condition can affect anyone but mostly athletes who participate in high-impact sports. Some examples of this may be runners, basketball players, or even soccer players. To treat this condition, it is recommended to ice the affected area and rest for the time being. Some other treatments may include wearing proper footwear with shock-absorbing insoles or arch supports.

I hope this answered your question. Please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.

Have a great day!

It is commonly caused by participating in high-impact activities, wearing poorly fitting shoes, or having a foot deformity. At-home treatments such as rest, ice, and wearing proper footwear with shock-absorbing insoles or arch supports can often relieve symptoms. Runners are particularly at risk for metatarsalgia, but anyone who participates in high-impact sports or wears poorly fitting shoes is also at risk.

This article aims to raise awareness of metatarsalgia and provide information on how to prevent and treat it. The message is that proper footwear and shock-absorbing insoles can help prevent or minimize future problems with metatarsalgia. The article also emphasizes the importance of rest and ice in treating the condition.

Yesterday. Today. Pieces propped up with supports. The therapist tapped his cigar. He no longer accepted her general opposition to myth, marriage, Olympic Games, and the course of decades. He said it was as if she were engaged in an eternal war, either watching a movie or acting in one, depending on the situation and time of day. She sat in silence, the sky above a half-baked blue, a blank- face dying of awkwardness. The simple explanation boiled down to the too-easy explanation. He was smart and charming then; and later, much less so. Behind his head, pictures were crammed together with the top layer hung so high she had to crane her neck to see the details. He said to please pretend she was listening.
